article.title: KiDS-450: Cosmological Constraints from Weak Lensing Peak Statistics-I: Inference from Analytical Prediction of High Signal-to-Noise Ratio Convergence Peaks

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the upper panel of Figure 1 primarily represent?
choices: The distribution of galaxy ellipticities in the KiDS-450 data.
The distribution of galaxy redshifts in the KiDS-450 data.
The abundance of weak lensing peaks as a function of their signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).
The correlation between weak lensing convergence and galaxy shapes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the error bars on the data points in the upper panel of Figure 1 represent?
choices: Uncertainties in the shape measurements of individual galaxies.
Uncertainties in the photometric redshifts of individual galaxies.
Statistical uncertainties in the peak counts derived from bootstrap resampling.
Systematic uncertainties due to the boost factor and baryonic effects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of the lower panel in Figure 1?
choices: To show the distribution of shape noise in the KiDS-450 data.
To illustrate the projection effects of large-scale structure on weak lensing peak counts.
To highlight the difference between the observed peak counts and the best-fit theoretical model.
To demonstrate the degeneracy between cosmological parameters Ωm and σ8.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following factors is NOT directly included in the formula for the number density of weak lensing peaks within halo regions?
choices: The cosmological volume element at redshift z.
The number of peaks within the virial radius of a dark matter halo.
The power spectrum of the weak lensing convergence field.
